intro: Dalechampia scandens var. hildebrandtii, commonly known as the Hildebrandt's beggar-tick, is a variant of the beggar-tick plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a flowering plant in the family Euphorbiaceae, characterized by its hairy stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers clustered in cup-like structures called cyathia, typical of the Euphorbiaceae family. Its fruit is a capsule that contains numerous tiny seeds, which are dispersed by wind. The plant is often found in moist, disturbed soils along stream banks and in wetlands.
